title: Grassholme Reservoir Walking Route

images.title: Andrew Smith / Grassholme Reservoir
images.caption: Grassholme Reservoir. Viewed from the path on its southern side. A steep bank drops to the water's edge.

images.title: Peter McDermott / Grassholme Reservoir
images.caption: Looking across Grassholme from Swarthy Top on a snowy day in December 2009

images.title: Andrew Smith / Grassholme Reservoir
images.caption: Looking across the middle of the reservoir from the inlet where Wester Beck enters it. On the other side is another inlet and the house at Stake Hill.

images.title: George Tod / Bridge at Head of Grassholme Reservoir
images.caption: Bridge at Head of Grassholme Reservoir. This road bridge is where the Pennine Way crosses Grassholme Reservoir in Lunedale.

images.title: Bird hide at Grassholme Reservoir Nature Reserve by peter robinson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bird hide at Grassholme Reservoir Nature Reserve. This is located at the western end of the site. Here you can look out for a wide variety of water loving wildlife.

images.title: Selset Weir by Trevor Littlewood, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Selset Weir. This can be found at the western end of the lake between the two reservoirs.

description: This circular walk follows the footpath around this lovely reservoir in upper Teesdale. The reservoir is surrounded by the Lune Valley countryside and woodland. The route runs for just over 3 miles on a fairly flat path so suitable for most abilities. Grassholme Reservoir is located a few miles south of Middleton in Teesdale . The Pennine Way runs past the reservoir so you could pick this up and head south to Balderhead, Blackton and Hury Reservoirs to extend your walk.
